quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: He also shares his experience with indexing towards choosing the harder option when you have multiple options to choose from and why that ends up making your life easier.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive decision rule (“choose the harder option”) framed as a way to reduce long-term complexity and effort.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Shopify is an incredibly interesting company because they have over 10,000 employees who are fully remote, and even though they were founded almost 20 years ago, they continue to operate with urgency, velocity and have very first principles, ways of thinking, which translates into them seeing record usage, blowing away their earnings calls just recently, and building a beloved product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example that remote scale and company age don’t have to reduce urgency—useful as a benchmark and cultural aspiration.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: A lot of this is thanks to Farhan, who in our conversation shares very specifically what he's done to maintain intensity and urgency within the engineering team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights that intensity/urgency can be actively maintained through specific practices, not just “set” by mission or leadership vibes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Including their meeting cadences, the counter-intuitive power of pair programming, how they run meetings, how they cancel meetings constantly and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Points to operational levers (cadences, pair programming, aggressively canceling meetings) that practitioners can directly experiment with.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: He also talks about their engineering intern program where they're going to hire over a thousand engineers just for their intern program in 2025.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A striking hiring scale data point that signals a deliberate pipeline strategy rather than incremental recruiting.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're an engineering leader or on a platform team, at some point your CEO will inevitably ask you for productivity metrics, but measuring engineering organizations is hard, and we can all agree that simple metrics like the number of PRs or commits doesn't tell the full story.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a common leadership challenge and warns against relying on simplistic output metrics that miss real productivity drivers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: DX is an engineering intelligence solution designed by leading researchers, including those behind the DORA and SPACE frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Points practitioners to established measurement frameworks (DORA, SPACE) as a foundation for thinking about engineering productivity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It combines quantitative data from developer tools with qualitative feedback from developers to give you a complete view of engineering productivity and the factors affecting it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable measurement approach: pair tool telemetry with developer sentiment to understand productivity and its root causes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What sets Persona apart is its configurability. Every company has different needs depending on its industry, use cases, risk tolerance, and user demographics.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break

quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Describes a concrete methodology for balancing growth and security: modular flows tuned to optimize conversion while controlling risk.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the hard path to learn
quotes.text: But the short version is that if you have a choice and you choose the easy thing and it works great. If you choose the hard thing and it works great, you did more work, but if it doesn't work and you chose the easy thing, you've actually not learned anything because you chose the... You haven't done a lot of work, you haven't probably worked with the smartest people because they're not usually around on the easy path, and what happens is you've gone through this exercise and now you're like, I've kind of lost.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A decision framework: the easy path has low learning upside when it fails, while the hard path compounds learning and talent exposure.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the hard path to learn
quotes.text: But if you do the hard path and it doesn't work, actually you still win because you've now done something hard. You've probably worked with smart people, you've learned something along the way that is valuable, and I can give you a quick example.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframe that “failure” on the hard path can still be a net win due to durable skill and relationship gains.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the hard path to learn
quotes.text: So I meet lots of job seekers and they're like, I go, "What are you doing to try to find a job?" I'm like, "I'm sending out 10 resumes a day." I'm like, "Okay." That sounds kind of easy, and are you really learning anything from sending out 10 resumes a day?
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A concrete example challenging the default job-search tactic by questioning whether it produces learning or leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the hard path to learn
quotes.text: Versus I would say to them, "Hey, you know all these companies you're interested in, Shopify might be one of them. Why don't you look at the API Docs and build something, build a Shopify app, build an admin extension, build something on top of Shopify."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Actionable alternative: build real artifacts on the platform you want to work with to create proof-of-work and skill growth.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the hard path to learn
quotes.text: And the same thing happened to me in taking hard courses. I would get worse marks, but I ended up meeting smarter people in those courses because they were there for the same reason I was because the content was hard.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A personal story illustrating that harder paths can trade short-term metrics (grades) for long-term network and learning benefits.

quotes.topic_title: When harder is better: people and learning
quotes.text: Yeah, one real one is of course the people, because I find that my path has always focused on trying to pick the best learning journey. Where can I learn the most?
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Reframes “harder is better” into an actionable selection criterion: optimize for maximum learning, especially via the people around you.

quotes.topic_title: When harder is better: people and learning
quotes.text: but for me, I learn a lot from people, and so I try to put myself in those harder rooms on purpose.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A practical tactic for growth: deliberately choose environments where you’re outmatched to accelerate learning through peers.

quotes.topic_title: When harder is better: people and learning
quotes.text: And so I would say a big part of it for me is yes, there's the how do you win even if you lose, because if it goes poorly, you can still come out of it with skills, but if you actually take the hard path, you'll have these intense working relationships with smart people that again will continue on in your life.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Introduces a resilience-oriented mental model: evaluate choices by what you gain even in failure—skills and durable relationships.

quotes.topic_title: When harder is better: people and learning
quotes.text: I mean, let's try to do the hard thing that we can learn from.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Clarifies the definition of “hard” as learning-rich difficulty rather than pointless complexity—useful for prioritization decisions.

quotes.topic_title: When harder is better: people and learning
quotes.text: Not everyone can look stupid in public over and over, but I believe it's my superpower and I try to make it my whole team's superpower too.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive team-culture principle: repeated public discomfort can be a scalable advantage for learning and growth.

quotes.topic_title: Looking stupid in public as a superpower
quotes.text: Not everyone can look stupid in public over and over, but I believe it's my superpower and I try to make it my whole team's superpower too.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable framing that normalizes repeated public failure as a learnable team capability, not just an individual trait.

quotes.topic_title: Looking stupid in public as a superpower
quotes.text: Half the time, by the way, when I say something dumb, people go, "I had the same question." They just were scared to say it.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Highlights how asking “dumb” questions can unlock hidden confusion and give others permission to speak up.

quotes.topic_title: Looking stupid in public as a superpower
quotes.text: And so maybe just the fact of going up and forcing myself to talk to people and then trying to get them to, and maybe you spend an hour with a client and then they don't buy anything, but you're getting that reaction of a bunch of negatives, and all you have to do is say, okay, and just go to the next customer.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A concrete practice for building rejection tolerance: treat “no” as a routine outcome and immediately move to the next attempt.

quotes.topic_title: Looking stupid in public as a superpower
quotes.text: I've definitely had that happen to me. And I'm like, "All right, let's move on to the next question."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Models a resilient response to harsh feedback—don’t internalize it; continue iterating toward understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Looking stupid in public as a superpower
quotes.text: I'm like, "Okay, I still don't get it." So my goal there is not to annoy the person, but it's to understand the content.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A simple mental model for persistence: prioritize comprehension over social comfort, even if it takes repeated asks.

quotes.topic_title: Learning from billionaires: vision and execution pairing
quotes.text: They're mostly different people, but they're similar in one thing is that they have an irrational view of what the world should look like over the next decade or so.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable pattern Farhan observed across multiple billionaire leaders: long-term, “irrational” vision as a common trait.

quotes.topic_title: Learning from billionaires: vision and execution pairing
quotes.text: And I'm not good at seeing that vision, but I'm good at trying to move towards that vision 1% a week.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Offers an actionable execution model—compounding weekly progress—paired with honest self-assessment of strengths.

quotes.topic_title: Learning from billionaires: vision and execution pairing
quotes.text: And so that is something that has resonated with me is like, how do I find these irrational all progress depends on the unreasonable man.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for deliberately seeking “unreasonable” partners to drive outsized progress.

quotes.topic_title: Learning from billionaires: vision and execution pairing
quotes.text: And even when I was starting my own company in 2015, I actually sat down and wrote a list of all the unreasonable people that I knew in Toronto, and I went down the list and met every single one of these entrepreneurs to figure out are we API compatible and could I work with them?
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A concrete, replicable methodology for founder-partner selection: list candidates, meet them all, and test “API compatibility.”

quotes.topic_title: Learning from billionaires: vision and execution pairing
quotes.text: So first of all, I just love this insight that being aware of this is not a superpower of mine and I'm not going to try to build it. I'm going to find someone to merge with, and connect your APIs together and be the person that builds it, not the person that envisions what to build.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian take on career growth: don’t force yourself to master every skill—partner to cover gaps and double down on execution.

quotes.topic_title: Using a written framework to choose jobs
quotes.text: And if you don't have a written down framework of the things you actually care about, it's very hard to be distracted. So very hard not to be distracted.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A practical mental model: writing your criteria down reduces the pull of shiny-object offers (title, money, brand).

quotes.topic_title: Using a written framework to choose jobs
quotes.text: So instead, I look at the framework and go, does this align with my framework? Right?
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A simple decision procedure for evaluating opportunities consistently.

quotes.topic_title: Using a written framework to choose jobs
quotes.text: Actually to the point of, I actually sent my framework to a recruiter one time and I said, "Hey, this thing," because they kept going back and forth to me and I go, "Hey, this doesn't align with my framework."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A concrete example of using the framework externally to save time and filter inbound recruiting.

quotes.topic_title: Using a written framework to choose jobs
quotes.text: When I realize that my framework is being violated, I will resign instantly and I've done that before.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A counterintuitive commitment device: treating values misalignment as an immediate exit trigger.

quotes.topic_title: Using a written framework to choose jobs
quotes.text: And so I encourage everyone, anybody looking for a job I always say, "Write down a framework. You can use mine as inspiration, but figure out what you care about and make sure that what you're working on lines up with that."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Direct, actionable advice to formalize personal values into a repeatable job-selection method.

quotes.topic_title: Resigning when the framework is violated
quotes.text: And so if I looked across my framework, it was violating all the things that I was trying to work.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Shows a practical decision trigger: explicitly evaluate a role against your personal framework and treat violations as a signal to act.

quotes.topic_title: Resigning when the framework is violated
quotes.text: I wasn't working with the smartest people anymore. I was on IC. I wasn't learning as much as I could be learning. And so I wasn't on this and I wasn't having a lot of impact.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Concrete checklist of misalignment signals (people, learning, impact) practitioners can use to assess whether to stay or leave.

quotes.topic_title: Resigning when the framework is violated
quotes.text: I was like, oh, wait a sec, this is completely not aligned.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Captures the moment of recognizing misalignment clearly enough to justify a decisive change rather than gradual rationalization.

quotes.topic_title: Resigning when the framework is violated
quotes.text: And then I just told the team, "Hey, I plan on resigning."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Models direct, fast action once the framework is violated—useful for leaders who tend to delay hard decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Resigning when the framework is violated
quotes.text: I'm just saying it at the time, lended me to say, "Hey, you're not actually focused on the right things."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Reframes resignation as a corrective mechanism for focus, not a failure—encouraging practitioners to prioritize the right drivers.

quotes.topic_title: Intensity: more output per minute, not more hours
quotes.text: One, I have this fundamental belief that one hour is one hour. It's the same hour. If you spend an hour or I spend an hour, it's the same time that goes by.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A simple mental model that reframes performance as output density within fixed time, not longer hours.

quotes.topic_title: Intensity: more output per minute, not more hours
quotes.text: If I can just get more done in the nine-to-five, we have both... The time has elapsed the same for us, but I just got more done.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Actionable focus on compressing work into standard hours to increase results without sacrificing life outside work.

quotes.topic_title: Intensity: more output per minute, not more hours
quotes.text: And pair programming is a great example because, so it's such an intense activity. Two people on one machine, you can get so much done when two people are working together, not being distracted by the internet and distractions, and just focus on writing the solution to the problem at hand.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for creating intensity by designing for focus and real-time collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Intensity: more output per minute, not more hours
quotes.text: And it's so tiring that usually when people switch on to pair programming, they sleep 10 to 12 hours a night the first few nights because it's so intense.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A vivid data point illustrating how intensity can be increased via work design rather than longer schedules.

quotes.topic_title: Intensity: more output per minute, not more hours
quotes.text: I'm like, what if you just did more per minute?
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A contrarian challenge to the common “work more hours” advice, emphasizing throughput per unit time.

quotes.topic_title: Pair programming as an underused management tool
quotes.text: It is the most underutilized management tool in engineering, bar none. It is just not used as much as it could be.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Frames pair programming not as a coding tactic but as a high-leverage management tool teams can adopt more broadly.

quotes.topic_title: Pair programming as an underused management tool
quotes.text: The throughput limiter is not hands-on keyboard.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A counterintuitive mental model: speed is constrained by thinking/design quality, not typing capacity.

quotes.topic_title: Pair programming as an underused management tool
quotes.text: And if they did not finish the problem in one hour, they would delete all the code and they would keep the tests and they would start over.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A concrete, extreme practice that combats sunk-cost bias and forces simpler designs while preserving correctness via tests.

quotes.topic_title: Pair programming as an underused management tool
quotes.text: Code is a liability and the right solution, the usually shorter lines, more elegant solution tends to appear after you've done a bunch of pathfinding.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Reframes code as long-term cost and justifies rewriting/deleting as a path to elegance after exploration.

quotes.topic_title: Pair programming as an underused management tool
quotes.text: The analogy I have is the underhanded free throw in basketball, statistically known to sink more baskets, but looks dumb and nobody does it.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Memorable analogy for adopting practices that work better despite social stigma—useful for driving cultural change.

quotes.topic_title: How Shopify uses pairing and AI copilots
quotes.text: Shopify is much more of a four to eight hour a week pair programming culture, where you're gathering together on a problem and saying, "Hey, let's pair for half a day, or let's pair every Wednesday."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A concrete operating model for using pairing selectively (time-boxed) rather than as a full-time default.

quotes.topic_title: How Shopify uses pairing and AI copilots
quotes.text: And so, you don't want to be pair programming for 18 months. You want to be wayfinding and pathfinding. And then go, "I see the matrix. Let me just delete everything and now build it." Because the learning is what you're going for. We have all the learning, now let's write the code.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A counterintuitive build strategy: optimize for learning first, then rewrite decisively once the problem is understood.

quotes.topic_title: How Shopify uses pairing and AI copilots
quotes.text: And then also we do a lot of pairing during an incident or a way to figure out together, work with somebody and say, "Hey, I'm not really sure and let's jump on a call together or jump on a tuple and go down the path."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Practical guidance on when pairing is highest leverage: uncertainty, debugging, and incident response.

quotes.topic_title: How Shopify uses pairing and AI copilots
quotes.text: So, AI is super interesting. What's happening right now with an AI copilot like GitHub Copilot is it is your pair programmer. So, you now can feel like you're pairing actually without another human. You can pair with the AI.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A memorable reframing of AI copilots as a new default pairing partner that changes solo development.

quotes.topic_title: How Shopify uses pairing and AI copilots
quotes.text: I would say, that's amazing. I would still contend take that experience and add two humans together. So you've got an AI copilot and humans, because what's happening is generating code. And the two humans can look and say, "Oh, I know what it's trying to do."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A “two humans + AI” methodology: use AI for generation, humans for interpretation, judgment, and direction.

quotes.topic_title: Operating cadence: weekly GSD and six-week reviews
quotes.text: Again, Parkinson's law at scale. If you ask people every week, they want to show progress every single week.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A simple operating mechanism (weekly updates) that leverages Parkinson’s Law to create consistent momentum and visible progress.

quotes.topic_title: Operating cadence: weekly GSD and six-week reviews
quotes.text: And now, we do six-week reviews. So, teams have this notion of every six weeks actually coming together and walking through the roadmap, the resourcing, and what they're working on with their immediate leadership, but then also, with Toby.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A concrete cadence for accountability and alignment that forces regular prioritization and resourcing decisions at the highest level.

quotes.topic_title: Operating cadence: weekly GSD and six-week reviews
quotes.text: We don't do change management, we just land it, and then go, "Hey everyone, it's a volatile company. This is what's happening. But this is how we get things done quickly." And then, move on with our lives.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A counterintuitive cultural stance: prioritize speed and resilience over smooth rollouts to reduce drag and decision latency.

quotes.topic_title: Operating cadence: weekly GSD and six-week reviews
quotes.text: And, within an hour we had increased the context on a bunch of major models and we were able to move forward through the thing, just because I asked.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A vivid example of unblocking execution by directly asking vendors—highlighting how “blocked” work can sometimes be solved instantly through escalation.

quotes.topic_title: Operating cadence: weekly GSD and six-week reviews
quotes.text: I'm like, "Well, did we just ask them if we get bigger?"
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A memorable prompt that encourages teams to challenge assumptions and try the simplest unblocker first: ask the obvious question.

quotes.topic_title: Micromanagement as pairing, not policing
quotes.text: the goal of the check-in is not for you to be like, "Ha, ha, I caught you not doing your work."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Reframes check-ins away from surveillance and toward a constructive purpose, which changes how leaders should run them.

quotes.topic_title: Micromanagement as pairing, not policing
quotes.text: It was hopefully to pair on the problem, meaning, when I ask somebody, "Hey, did we move forward on this LLM project, because we now have this larger context window?" And then, they came back and said, "Oh, here's what we learned." So then, I can then look at the answer and say, "Oh, so now, have you thought of this? Have you tried..." It's a way to pair on the problem.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Provides a concrete “pairing” model for frequent check-ins: ask for progress, learnings, then collaboratively iterate on next experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Micromanagement as pairing, not policing
quotes.text: we don't actually think it's a dirty word at Shopify, but the reason we don't think it's a dirty word is because it's not just, again, Dilbert boss saying, "Where did you do the thing?" It's like, "Hey, can I work on this problem with you? And if I work on this problem with you, I got to see where you are pretty often, and then give you advice, or you're going to share context with me, because I'm not in the work every day."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Turns “micromanagement” into a collaborative operating system: frequent touchpoints as a mechanism for context-sharing and coaching.

quotes.topic_title: Micromanagement as pairing, not policing
quotes.text: Well, he goes, "Oh, you misunderstand why you're here. We are here to work on problems together."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A memorable leadership expectation: senior leaders aren’t just delegators—they’re partners in solving the hardest problems.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting Armageddon and reducing Slack distraction
quotes.text: Once a year at a random time, we will delete all recurring meetings that have more than two people, so not one-on- ones, and are internal people only, so not interviews or external partner meetings. And then, we have a two-week moratorium where you're not allowed to add a reoccurring meeting. You can have a regular meeting, but not a reoccurring meeting.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable methodology (“meeting reset” + moratorium) for breaking recurring-meeting inertia.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting Armageddon and reducing Slack distraction
quotes.text: And the idea is that there's a lot of inertia behind a recurring meeting. It just always is there, and you know it's coming up, and it's hard to delete, because you're like, "Oh yeah, we talk about this thing every week."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A mental model explaining why recurring meetings persist and why a forced reset can be necessary.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting Armageddon and reducing Slack distraction
quotes.text: So, we're at something like three hours of meetings per week for an individual contributor at Shopify, which is phenomenal. Three hours a week is amazing. I think managers is not that bad. I think I tweeted this. I think it's six or seven hours per week. That's not bad at all, in order to get aligned. And then, all the rest of the time is work time.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: A specific benchmark for meeting load that teams can use as a target for protecting maker time.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting Armageddon and reducing Slack distraction
quotes.text: But, it came down by something like 50 or 60%. It was something like five or six hours for individual contributors and came down to three. And then, the managers, I think it was 10 that came down to 6, something like that.
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: Quantifies the impact of the interventions, showing large reductions in meeting time for both ICs and managers.

quotes.topic_title: Meeting Armageddon and reducing Slack distraction
quotes.text: So, anytime you're sending a status update or large group announcement, we moved all of that to Facebook Meta Workplace, like Facebook for work basically, which is now being deprecated. So, we'll have to figure that out. But, it just moved all this stuff to a ML feed that you can consume differently than you would Slack, because Slack is like I message you and you see an alert and all this stuff, versus Workplace is like, "Oh, I want to go and consume content from the company, and get updates, and share updates."
quotes.speaker: Farhan Thawar
quotes.context: An actionable comms pattern: move broadcast updates out of interrupt-driven chat into a pull-based feed to reduce distraction.
